name: Nom Wah Tea Parlor
address: 13 Doyers St, New York, NY 10013, USA

reviews.text: it is overrated. Some of the dim sum was cold- I think it was already prepared prior to ordering.
If you want old time Cantonese fun sum, them you need to go to Nom Wah.  The food is delicious.
Great food. Found this place by accident

Obviously, if a restaurant in NYC is open more than a few months, it's got to have decent food. If a restaurant has been open in NYC for a few years, the food is most likely world class. If a restaurant in NYC has been open for decades, the food has to be world class, and the cost of eating there has to be reasonable. I was born and raised in Brooklyn, traveled the world, this has been my experience.
Nom Wah Tea Parlor has the best Cantonese food I have ever eaten (I have not been to China). The kicker is this, wait for it....
The prices are very reasonable! What??? World class Cantonese Food, in NYC, full belly for 3 people, under $100. best kept secret on the NYC food scene. Bar none!

Restaurante chino de toda la vida con comida oriental a precios econÃ³micos. La bebida siempre es cara en todos los restaurantes. El agua es gratis. La Ãºnica pega de este sitio es que solo aceptan American express o dinero en metÃ¡lico. No aceptan ninguna otra tarjeta. Recomendable visitar.
It's basically dim sum that's way over priced but it's in alleyway or something and has a photogenic facade so they get the tourists. Food was good but definitely not worth the money.

Really understated but homely food. All the flavours youâ€™d expect from dim sum, everything seems to be made fresh. Great pitstop but nothing fancy.

As to the incident we may or may not have had with service when paying for our meal. Iâ€™m not 100% confident but me and my folks have a suspicion one of the servers pocketed $20 when counting our cash (Amex or cash only). Server stepped away turned his back and returned saying we were twenty short. Upon leaving I noticed he pulled more cash from his pocket from behind the bar. again, Iâ€™m NOT certain but it feels strange enough for me to bring up. Couldâ€™ve been tips? I hope so.

Fabulous dim sum in authentic China Town environment.

Unfortunately this restaurant only takes either cash or AMEX credit card and they do not tell you until they have seated you. Food was stale and not as fresh compared to other dim sum Chinese restaurants in Chinatown. The waiters usually stand near you or behind you to ensure you tip them at least 18%. If you do not tip them at least 18% in tip, they will not let you leave and chase after you until you have paid them. Absolute disgrace and disrespectful to the culture.
Simply awful. DO NOT waste your time here. Find any other chinese restaurant just not this one
I was with a friend ans we both experienced how bad this place was. Only the decor is good. The most important part was the food and that was inedible
Food is a disgrace to real chinese cuisine

Iâ€™ve been coming to this place for many years, but unfortunately, the quality of the food has declined. Itâ€™s still known for offering affordable dim sum, but the flavors have become lackluster and the buns are often dry. Itâ€™s disappointing because the dishes look great, but the taste doesnâ€™t live up to the presentation.
Cash only, requiring customers to tip when service quality is poor

Weâ€™ve visited this restaurant multiple times and we love it! Itâ€™s one of the best dim sum restaurants in New York City. Our favorites are the Roast Pork Bun, Scallion Pancakes, Spring Rolls, Shrimp and Bacon Rolls. While it can get busy with a long waiting line, the food is served incredibly quickly. Love the old diner-style ambiance and decor. Thereâ€™s plenty of both indoor and outdoor seating. The staff is always friendly and welcoming. I highly recommend dining here!
Great meal I don't like the rush job though they stand over folks while they eat
The place and the atmosphere of the restaurant are nice, but the dumplings are bland and we notice poor quality ingredients!

One of the better Chinese restaurant that I always go to.  This time was a bit of disappointment.  The scallion pancake was just a crispy flat bread with barely a trace of scallion. The stuffed eggplant is always on point.

Noticed that they tell customers upfront that they only take cash or Amex.
Fantastic heritage place hidden from busy streets, delicious food and authentic experience!
Good
ä¸€é–“è€ç‰ŒèŒ¶å®¤ï¼Œç’°å¢ƒä¸éŒ¯ï¼Œä½†é¤é»æ²’æœ‰ä»€éº¼ç‰¹è‰²ï¼Œå£å‘³æ¯”è¼ƒè¥¿åŒ–ã€‚
This place was delicious and authentic!!! They only take cash or Amex, btw. But the tea and food was perfection. No notes. So yummy.

All of these food and it was $23/person (tip included!!)

We got there early so there was no waiting at all. Highly recommend the Sui Mai, House Special Roast Pork Bun, Shrimp & Snow Pea Leaf!! Great comfort food and dont forget to get some tea!

Will definitely come back for good casual food:)

Great vibes and yummy dim sum! My favorite were the soup dumplings and shrimp dumplings. Excellent value for the price, just make sure you have cash :) Beautiful interior and they served us very quickly.
Everything is good hereâ€¦. Worth the wait in line every time!
really not good if youâ€™re vegan :( wish they had more vegan options, or even vegetarian. but my non-vegan friends really liked it!

The dim sum is good, the atmosphere is old time diner meets Chinatown. Great place for families or a date. The food was yummy, Iâ€™d prefer the rice rolls to be a bit hotter, but the soups and Siu Mai were super tasty. The service was attentive and kind.

Chinatown is full of dumpling and Dim Sum places, and must of them are basically good, with few the top the rest. Thus is the oldest place for dumplings and dim sum, and the food here is good. I love the fact they left everything as it used to be many years ago, it gives the place some magic. I had Vegetarian Dumplings ğŸ¥Ÿ ,
Cilantro ğŸŒ¿ and Scallion Rice ğŸš Rolls and Minced Beef Dumplings Soup, the rice rolls were good but not warm enough, the vegetarian dumplings were ok , the soup was luck of flavor and I had to add some spicy sauce to give it some taste. Service is nice and welcoming, vibe of old times, like in a time tunnel. It is ok but not must to visit

Unforgettable experience!
Amazing food, great tea and fantastic atmosphere.
Who could imagine that with a 30-minute subway ride you can find such an amazing experience.

Nom Wah Tea Parlor is a true NYC classic. As the oldest dim sum spot in the city, it carries an old-school charm that instantly transports you back in time the moment you walk in. The food matches the vibe; high-quality dim sum thatâ€™s tough to beat.

Their chicken feet are hands-down the best Iâ€™ve had in the city; tender, flavorful, and done perfectly. Everything else on the menu is consistently good too, making it a reliable go-to whether youâ€™re introducing someone to dim sum or just craving it yourself.

The mix of history, atmosphere, and unbeatable quality makes Nom Wah an experience every New Yorker (and visitor) should have at least once.

Mi aspettavo un poâ€™ di piÃ¹, soprattutto per la storia di questo locale. Ho preso tre portate, la numero 1, 8 e 13. Il riso non sono riuscita ad apprezzarlo perchÃ© mi aspettavo qualcosa di piÃ¹ saporito. I ravioli con brodo erano invece la fine del mondo. Il baozi buono. Complessivamente mi Ã¨ dispiaciuto trovare un servizio poco affabile. Forse non amano i turisti. Non ho capito. O forse Ã¨ il loro modo di fare. Senza considerare che appena sono entrata, la persona che mi ha accolto mi ha chiesto subito se avrei pagato in contanti. Al che ho risposto che se necessario avrei pagato in contanti, come se fosse una discriminante. Lui ha ripetuto contanti. Il locale Ã¨ invece letteralmente stupendo, con tocchi vintage originali. Peccato sia tenuto malissimo. Non solo non Ã¨ stata fatta alcuna opera di conservazione, ma câ€™Ã¨ tanta incuria e sembra tutto appiccicaticcio. Il bagno no comment. I prezzi sono contenuti.

Food at this establishment is phenomenal. I'm addicted to those fried sesame balls...literally. This restaurant gets packed out on the weekends due to high foot traffic and sometimes language barrier can be an issue, but the food makes up for that. Must try.

Went there 6 weeks ago and ordered the OMG egg roll and got food poisoning. 3 weeks of boils running up and down my legs. Worst yet, I think they did it on purpose. The waiter and the cash register lady could not even look me in the eyes when I paid for the meal. These people are just to envious of the customers they serve.  Nasty place...
A real Asian treat, right down to the indifferent service. Amazing food but sketchy bathrooms.

Saw nom wah tea parlor have no lines or wait after decades of trying to go here. There was a rainstorm so the stars aligned like some movie. Food was freaking delicious and itâ€™s so beautiful in there.

Terrible. Fuimos a tomar unas bebidas y postre pues ya no era la hora de la comida para nosotros. Desde que entramos los meseros con cara de enojados. Cuando llegaron a tomar la orden y vieron que solo querÃ­amos dos postres y cinco tÃ©s, se enojaron y dijeron que cada persona tenÃ­a que pedir un plato! Que asÃ­ no nos podÃ­an servir. Obviamente nos levantamos y nos fuimos. Ni ganas de volver a ese vejestorio.
Great soup dumplings. Fast service.
The Phoenix buns are godly
IYKYK â€” better tip well
Must stop, this is a legend in NYC Chinatown. No wait, server came right over, food came fast. Not the best dumplings, not a michelin starred place but so worth the stop.

We arrived on a sunday for a dim sum brunch. Arrogantly met with servers pretending to not know english. We ordered the og eggroll, which was unlike any eggroll I have had before. Basically a crepe filled with fresh veggies dipped and flour and fried. I enjoyed it. Then we got the soup dumpling which were on the line of trader joes frozen ones and the pork and shrimp shumai which were pretty tasty. Prices were decent. I gave a 25 percent tip and the waitress didnt seem happy about it????? I would recommend the place if u want to experience a 3rd world country feeling walking there. I prob wont go back much better in the area like dim sum gogo
Been going there for a quarter century and nothing has changed (that's a good thing!)

this place is great. I do have to say the wait to get in is not ideal and I think you can get great dim sum at many places in Chinatown. maybe even better than here. the egg rolls are very interesting a soft creamy center wrapped in thin egg and tossed in batter and fried. I loved them but not for everyone. also loved the shrimp and onion shu mai. pan fried dumplings were great as well.

good food, friendly & fast service. only by cash or american express

Das dreckigste Restaurant in dem ich jemals gegessen habe. Das Essen OK, mehr nicht, der Service war ebenfalls nur OK, aber die Hygiene eine Zumutung. Wer immer der Besitzer des Ladens ist sollte sich schÃ¤men. Absolut ekelhaft!

Extremely rude and pushy staff. Worst experience I've had anywhere in the country and I've traveled widely. I gave them a 15% tip (they only accept cash) and the server became visible upset and refused to accept my payment and let us leave. The pointed to the receipt which had suggested tip options of 18, 20, and 25%. I almost always tip 20% or more but I didn't think the service was even average -- they wouldn't refill our water and were generally rude the whole time. Don't go here, try Dim Sum Palace instead.
Left disappointed, we were expecting a lot more from being the oldest Dim Sum place in Chinatown. Food was bland and dry. Tea was good.
Extremely affordable. Authentic and yummy too.
